screens.headline: Pay money or collect money?
screens.text: Same stock, same outlook, but one spread costs you money (debit) and the other pays you money (credit). Which is better?

screens.headline: The fundamental choice in spreads
screens.text: Debit spreads = You pay money upfront. Credit spreads = You collect money upfront. Debit spreads have higher profit potential. Credit spreads have higher probability of profit. You cannot have both - it's always a trade-off.

screens.headline: Lottery ticket vs insurance company
screens.text: Debit spread = Buying a lottery ticket. You pay $5, and if you're right, you win $20. Small cost, big payout, low probability. Credit spread = Being the insurance company. You collect $200/month in premiums. Most months nothing happens and you keep it. If disaster strikes, you pay out $1,000. High probability of small wins, occasional big loss.

reveal_sections.label: Debit = Pay small, win big (lottery player)
reveal_sections.content: You pay upfront for the chance at a larger payout if your directional bet is correct.

reveal_sections.label: Credit = Collect premium, occasional loss (insurance company)
reveal_sections.content: You collect money upfront and keep it if the stock doesn't move against you.

reveal_sections.label: Neither is 'better' - depends on your strategy
reveal_sections.content: Choose based on your conviction level and risk tolerance.

cards.definition: Buy lower call + Sell higher call = Pay money
Sell higher put + Buy lower put = Collect money
Buy higher put + Sell lower put = Pay money
Sell lower call + Buy higher call = Collect money

screens.question: Which spread type typically has a HIGHER probability of profit?
screens.explanation_correct: Correct! Credit spreads have higher probability because you're taking the 'insurance company' side. You collect premium and profit as long as the stock doesn't move too much against you.
screens.explanation_wrong: Credit spreads win more often. Why? You collect premium upfront and profit if the stock stays flat OR moves in your direction. Debit spreads need directional movement to profit.

screens.question: You're moderately bullish on AAPL at $180. Which spread should you choose?
screens.explanation_correct: Great choice! 'Moderately bullish' suggests you want higher probability over massive gains. Bull put spreads profit if AAPL stays flat OR goes up.
screens.explanation_wrong: The word 'moderately' is key. When you're not expecting a huge move, credit spreads (bull put) are better because they have higher win rates. Save debit spreads for strong conviction moves.

screens.headline: Compare credit vs debit
screens.description: MSFT at $400, you're bullish to $420. Compare two approaches to the same outlook.

Trade-off: Credit spread risks more to make the same profit
Debit spread has better risk/reward but lower probability

cards.back: Strong directional conviction. Don't mind lower win rate for better risk/reward. Expect significant move.
Moderate conviction. Want higher probability. Okay with smaller gains for consistent wins.
Debit: Pay $1 to make $3 (33% win rate needed). Credit: Collect $1, risk $2 (67% win rate needed).
